div1.p: Carter is restructuring the bibliographic references to the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever according to Frost's suggestion.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, January 18, 1929
div1.opener:
Book. Misel
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
January 18, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I have been, and am, so busily engaged in carrying out Dr.
Frost's suggestions of Xmas week for the revision and rearrangement
of many of the remaining bibliographic cards that I've been too
tired, when I came to"a good place to stop", to report progress to you.
There has been considerable progress during the past week and I hope
to have a “unit” of material ready to send over to Dr. Frost by the
end of this week. I have a lot of completed work here now, but the
references of each Section of the book are so inter-dependent that I
have to keep them together until they have all been straightened out
and arranged by a new method, of Dr. Frost's which should greatly expeditee his Frost'shis
checking.

Miss Brown was still on sick leave this morning, but telephoned
that she shoped to be able to put in a half-day's work at the Library
of Congress this afternoon and to come to my apartment on Sunday to
resume work on the book. I have certainly missed her both personally
and for her trained and enthusiastic co-operation in the work.

Were there any such thing as “chronic flu” I'd say I had it! Still
running subnormal temperatures in the morning with slight fever in the
afternoon, and getting very tired of it. However, since the very men-
tion of such a malady is in the same category with certain heretical
observations ofn a similar type of yellow fever, I am looking forward to
finally outliving this particular unpleasantness. Also, so long as
the thing is merely unpleasant and does not interfere with my work it
can be borne with philosophy, if not with resignation.

With very best wishes, and trusting that the next time you come
come
-2-
to Washington I shall have the pleasure of seeing you
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
We are all deeply grieved about Goldberger's death. As Noguchi
said to me, in speaking of Father: “It is ill that such men must die!”--
A saying equally appropriate to Noguchi himesself!
L.A.C.
